newsitem.title: USA: Disney's "Dalmatians" hold top spot at box office.
newsitem.headline: Disney's "Dalmatians" hold top spot at box office.

text.p: Walt Disney Co.'s (DIS.N "101 Dalmatians" held the top spot at the U.S. box office for the second week in a row, comfortably fending off Sylvester Stallone's new movie, "Daylight," according to studio estimates released Sunday.

"101 Dalmatians," which stars Glenn Close in a live-action remake of the studio's 1961 animated hit, earned an estimated $13.5 million during the Friday to Sunday weekend. Since opening Nov. 27, the movie has earned $62 million.

Opening in second this weekend was Stallone's low-end disaster picture "Daylight" with $10.2 million. The movie is released by Universal Pictures, a unit of Seagram Co. Ltd. VO.TO. Stallone plays a taxi driver who rescues people trapped in a New York tunnel.

Third place this weekend went to "Star Trek: First Contact," which earned an estimated $6.65 million. Its gross to date is $71.2 million. The movie is released by Paramount Pictures, a unit of Viacom Inc. VIA.A.

Battling for fourth were the Arnold Schwarzenegger Christmas comedy "Jingle All the Way" and Mel Gibson's kidnap thriller "Ransom," each of which reported $5.4 million. "Jingle All the Way," which is released by News Corp.'s NCP.AX 20th Century Fox, has earned $37.8 million to date. Disney's "Ransom" has secured $112.8 million.

Woody Allen's new movie, "Everyone Says I Love You," opened in limited release in order to qualify for Oscar consideration. The musical earned $134,000 from three screens, giving it a melodious average of $44,667. By contrast, the highest average in the top 10 was $4,801 for "101 Dalmatians," which played in 2,812 theaters. Allen's movie is released by Disney-owned Miramax Films.
